item.title: I've been thinking
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded:
And it's not anyone specific, so don't start worrying and/or asking.
Have any of you ever noticed that it's only rarely -- if at all -- that we have the same impact on the lives of those that affect us most?
It seems to me that the people that matter to us are frequently focused on other things. And i wonder why that is -- is it a causal relationship, do they affect us _because_ they are focused elsewhere? Do we by default pursue those whose interests lie in spheres that only tangentially intersect our own? And why?
Despite my disclaimer above, this is more than a little bit significant to me. I've never had the knack of making lots of friends, but the few i do make are very good friends, and thus very valuable to me, so it behooves me to figure out how best to treat with them, and how to get the most value out of the friendship -- for both them and I.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I've been mulling this one over for a day now. It occurs to me that perhaps I'm being presumptuous in commenting, given that I havn't known you long. My apologies if that should be the case.
I'm in roughly the same situation as far as friendships are concerned. I haven't met anyone I've felt the urge to keep in contact with in four years of university courses and I can count on one hand the number of people I've kept in contact with outside that context. Oddly, many of the people I do consider 'friend' are similar in that respect. But then, consider that these same people are the sort who have a few good long-term friends and for whom expanding that social network isn't a high priority.
It hit me sometime about three years ago that it's downright difficult to maintain the same close contact one enjoyed with friends in grade school. Everyone's lives diverge in some way past that point; it's hard to avoid.
At the same time, one has expectations of how a friend is going to behave. Someone who consitantly backs one up, whom one can feel safe talking to without fear of judgement, is, no matter how infrequently one sees them, going to make an impact. I remember being absolutely devestated by an off-hand comment from someone I'd thought I could trust to be impartial years ago. It didn't matter that we had drifted due to various moves; it still *hurt*.
It's a difficult situation. On the one hand, someone one spends time with constantly will (in theory) know one well enough not to make an unwittingly tactless comment. On the other, some of the most engaging and enduring friendships can be found with people one hardly sees. Any time one trusts someone enough to consider that person a friend, there is an ability for that person to either leave one feeling grounded and appreciated by that friendship, or shattered by some act of thoughtlessness.
As far as the causal aspect of a relationship goes, I'm drawn to think that any time someone sets aside a few hours of their life to devote to a friend, it's going to make an impact on the other person. By doing so, one shows that the relationship is important. At the same time, someone whom one hardly sees but who makes it clear that taking the time for the relationship is important to *them* as much as it is to oneself, is going to make a bigger impact than someone who acts as though they have something better to be doing at the time. So, yes, I believe there is a cause-and-effect involved, just not one necessarily based on how wrapped up in the rest of their lives in proportion to the friendship the people involved are.
In that vein, I'm not inclined to believe that one's interests in relation to a friend's are anything more than a convienient jumping point for a conversation. It's fantastic listening to someone talk passionately about something one may know very little about oneself, particularly if that person has the ability to make one think that _hey, that *is* pretty amazing_, even if one doesn't feel the urge to pursue it oneself.
This is a subject my own mind has circled back to on more than a few occasions. I hope I haven't been too pompous in addressing it.
You've a knack for asking the questions that demand consideration. I'm not about to pretend that this one has any easy or concrete answer, but I do think it's an important one to think on.
On that note, I want to thank you and Char for being so welcoming. I tend to feel awkward around people I don't know well, and the two of you have gone a long way toward proving that most people won't bite. Nor have you made me feel like the superfluous girlfriend-of-a-friend; I've come to enjoy your company. I appreciate that.

First off, no, not at all presumptuous. For two reasons, in fact -- number one, if I didn't want anyone to comment on it, I wouldn't post it to a public forum, and number two, you _specifically_ are more than welcome to provide input.
I think that for me it's a matter of having interests that, like yourself, are rather esoteric, and finding it hard to find conversational common ground with even my closes friends sometimes. It's not a stretch to say that my greatest, most all-pervasive fear is that i'll run out of things to say and be abandoned by all due to my being, fundamentally, a very boring person.
Which is not to say that I think i'm boring, but I do have a narrow band of interests, and it's not one that many share.
The distance thing is something i'm dealing with really directly right now, as one of my good friends has drifted away from me -- and i from him -- over the last two years, after a forceful break. It's being brought to the fore again by a mutual friend who, sensibly, isn't about to stop being _either_ of our friends, and so the old association feels a bit more tender. As a result, i'm putting a fair amount more time into thinking about this kind of thing.
The causal bit stems admittedly from a bit of self-pity -- i have always felt as though i'm the follower, the one calling, etc... I know, intellectually, that this isn't true, and that I've had a positive impact on the lives of my friends as well. Or at least I think so. But it's a long-ingrained habit to think otherwise, and it's a hard one to break. My friends are the most precious things i have, having few of them, and as such i always feel that i have to put out a lot of effort... Especially given that my friendships are far scarcer than those of most people i know.
And regarding your latter point, it's far from being an effort. Both Char and i don't think of you as a "girlfriend-of-a-friend" but as a friend in your own right. So, of course you're welcome. Although, we have been known to bite, on occasion ;)

Tangential and overdue ramblings from an overtired mind, here.
Wait. First line and already a self-depreciating disclaimer. Pah. Let's try that again, shall we?
Having read this nearly thirty-six hours ago, I've ruminated on it quite a bit -- at the expense of sleep when most needed -- and came up with more questions than answers, leading to some late-night think-sessions that went in some odd directions.
A number of things stated in your post, when viewed from a different direction, lead to some (admittedly wildly speculative) things, self-depreciating nonsense aside. For instance, "[i]t seems to me that the people that matter to us are frequently focused on other things. And i wonder why that is is it a causal relationship, do they affect us because they are focused elsewhere?" to me, smacks of commentary on unrequited love and the human habit of chasing things, people and pursuits to the detriment of the self in favour of the not-self. This in turn led me down some twisted mental paths, seeking, and failing, to pinpoint the link between friendship and love.
One thing I can answer, however, is your implied question regarding "how best to treat [my friends], and how to get the most value out of the friendship". Simple, really. Be you. Forget the multiple masks of self; be self. Shed the fictionsuit of social convention and allow people to view you for you are.
Like yourself, I've never had the knack for making (or sustaining, for that matter) friendships. This is due to a number of factors, though most prevalent is my unwillingness to change who I am in favour of who others want me to be, and my profession, which tends to lead to infrequent occasion for socialization. Still, those that I do count among my friends I can do so wholeheartedly, knowing that they know me and enjoy me for who I am.

Speculation is really the goal of posts like this anyway, since -- let's be realistic -- this doesn't have any solid, _real_ answers. If there's one thing my limited knowledge of psychology has taught me it's that causes are rarely separable from effects when dealing with other humans. And, as a result, there's really not a lot we can expect to glean over the long run from looking into those, other than a clearer view of our _own_ causes.
Which is a good thing, in and of itself, to be sure.
I'm just glad that whatever it is i'm doing, it seems to be working. More to the point, it's getting me the friends i want, rather than the friends that i've had in the past, to whom i clung more out of a sense of desperation than any real gain on my part. Even though they're few, i've at least got _real_ friends :)

One thing I'd really appreciate is not to have my political orientation mocked at every good opportunity. there are a lot of stupid left wing people. I've met some. I'm dismayed by them. I met someone once who told me a friend of his thought Marx was the way of the future for every single country on Earth. I thought that was one of the stupidest things I've ever heard. I'm not a communist. I'm not some kind of environment/[insert cause here] kook. I also know a lot of stupid right wing people but don't equate you with them and try not to make jokes about right wingers around you. (if I do, let me know, and I'll stop). You've heard me make Bush jokes and bad mouth him, but you've also heard and acknowledged my well thought out reasons for disliking him and his policies. I even have well thought out reasons for not liking Klein! But I won't go into those here. Thanks

item.title: Flat-out scared
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded:
I talked to the [U of A Registrar](http://www.registrar.ualberta.ca/) today about my application for admission -- the one that has been accepted for pretty much every other student in my class. You know, the ones whose cumulative marks fall short of mine?
They seem to have "lost" the file.
It's not that they don't have the information, but they don't know why I haven't heard back, or anything at all about my status as a would-be University student. Thus, I am in limbo. Not a successful applicant to the U. Spinning my wheels. And, of course, scared shitless that something went wrong, they're not going to take me, and i'm fucked.
Realistically, what the hell am I going to do if they _don't_ accept me? Just say "Oh, well! Back to $(MENIAL SHITWORK JOBSITE) for me!" and keep right on smiling? Christ. What a horrible idea.
As it is, even if they do accept me, i'm already too late to apply for all the plum course sessions -- the ones with only 12 students that are probably going to be where the interesting and motivated people are, with the funky projects and high-quality teaching. Basically, I'm going to be stuck -- yet again -- with the same shithead classmates that i've had to endure for two years to _get_ to the U of A and, what's more, **THEY'RE ALREADY ACCEPTED AND I'M NOT!!!!**
FUCK!
I have to go now. Study for exams... Although I wonder if it's worth bothering at this point.
### Mood Swing
I just spoke to a very nice lady at the Faculty of Science who apparently heard my concern and called the Registrar's office on my behalf, finding out that -- in fact -- the application is now in the process of being prescreened and should be sent over to them soon. What's more, she said that when they received it they'd fast-track the evaluation of it, to minimize futher delays.
/me breathes a _massive_ sigh of relief.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Welcome to the smooth running, efficient bureaucracy of the UofA. I hope they sort that out for you soon. (read: by Monday).
As for the sessions that are full that you want to get into, go to your department office and you should be able to apply to get in. Given your circumstances, they might accept one more person. I had this happen to me once, so I applied for special permission to enroll in a full class and was given a vacant grad student spot. (the undergrad spots were all full). I think that you have good reason to go and check.

I agree with mel. Our Math Phys 468 class (general relativity) was full in like, 5 days, and so victor couldn't get in - so they ended up adding 10 new slots to the class. Just talk to the advisors, they might probably be able to help. I mean, these are rather extenuating circumstances.

item.title: Database Headbeatery
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded:
For the last few weeks i've been poking at the edges of a new project, something to take the edge off of my general inability to keep track of appointments, schedules, etc. A long time ago, i was using MS Outlook for this, but i had to switch off of it since i started using IMAP mail -- Outlook is great in some ways, but it's really weak in IMAP support unless you're using the (very expensive) Exchange server.
Anyway, this having been decided, I started investigating J2EE(Java 2 Enterprise Edition) solutions. For those who don't know, J2EE is probably the most complex server side programming system in the whole universe. It's debatable whether even God could code in this without losing some sleep over it.
What's my point?
After many days of pain and sturm and drang, I made my webserver talk to a database, and tell it to do things. And what's more, i made it do this stepping through all the hoops that J2EE so nicely tangles in a pile in front of developers.
Yes, it's a small thing. But it's *damned* satisfying.

item.title: Power for the upcoming generation
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: In the news recently, a leading Green thinker wrote a call to action directed at environmentalist groups urging them to accept nuclear power as a necessary measure to control climate change before it's too late. As one can imagine, the usual suspects immediately had the usual knee-jerk reactions to the suggestion, thus combining both the valid premise that arguments from authority should not necessarily be accepted at face value, and the faulty one that says that "Nuclear is bad, no matter what, no matter how," which stems from... what? Nuclear energy has the interesting distinction, according to some discussion of it that I've read, of being the only form of generated "dirty" power that actually visits its primary harmful effects on humans, as opposed to the other creatures we share the planet with. From some accounts, both Bikini Atoll and the Chernobyl region are thriving ecologies, where the flora and fauna have lived quite happily and comfortably. Which is not to say that there's nothing bad about Nuclear Power, but it does kind of hint that it might be a good way to handle the growing need for electricity without resorting to burning more fossil fuels. Which, of course, should be saved for _important_ things, like powering SUVs and such. Anyway, regardless of the actual value of the proposition, I find it depressing that organizations that claim to be committed to doing the best they can for the earth steadfastly refuse to examine solutions that exist outside their faith (see my earlier post about environmentalism == religion). This news item gets some interesting discussion on Slashdot and probably on Mefi, but the latter is down.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
there is, too, the ramification of new (or the popularization of other) resources on the government conglomerate, supported by its various corporate partners, which is an aspect not to be overlooked.
we have not seen the mass marketing of hemp products because of the potential effects on logging, cotton, and fuel industries, traditional big money players in the marketplace and in government pocketbooks. and then of course the hydro/power/utility players, too...
until the "old boys club" goes and a more broad-sighted generation comes to power, i wouldn't wager on seeing much prevalence of nuclear power or any other "alternative" resource.

Wind power all the way. It's the one thing Alberta will never run out of.
But let's use the remaining fossil fuels to destroy SUVs, not power them. Especially hummers. I really like your idea that they should pay more at the tank, and frankly, Hummers and those stupid Dodge Hemi things out to be outlawed. If I was running for PM, I'd make a whole environmental campaign out of that. I'd lose all the voters in Alberta, but probably gain most of the voters in Ontario, especially if I offered tax breaks to owners of low emission cars (then Char would vote for me) and hybrid cars. Work vehicles (necessary ones, I mean) and semis would be excluded automatically. I like the way this sounds. Then maybe people would stop buying idiot vehicles and buy vehicles that aren't responsible for the most accidents and won't single handedly kill the planet.
but you never know. maybe one day, the sick fleet of st. albert soccer moms really will take to the off road...

I can remember spending much of my earlier life striving with all I had to be whatever it took to get people to like me. I would do anything asked of me, if I thought it had any hope whatsoever of making people appreciate me.
As years went by, though, as opposed to specifically "finding myself," rather I ended up becoming more and more cynical about human nature and the world around me. I didn't so much find _myself_ as determine in more detail and breadth what i _didn't want to be_. This, of course, is not the same thing at all.
It seems to me that I had two watershed events in my life occur at more or less the same time, though, that combined to really give me ... not direction, because I was still rudderless for some time after that, but I guess you could call it hope. Not for life, because life itself was still pretty harsh on me, but more that I would come to be somebody that was independent and able to build a self without reference to the expectations of others. So for that, I have Amanda and (ironically) moving to Edmonton to thank.
Over the years since then, I've gone through a lot. A failed engagement, and another failed relationship that bears no further mention here. I've tried (and failed repeatedly) to get back into school. I've worked jobs that sucked, and jobs that sucked more. I've diversified my tastes in art and focused my passion for computers. I have met and become friends with the best people I have hever had in my life, save for the few who predate my move to Edmonton.
And more importanly, I have become (mostly) comfortable with who I am. I realize that the way I think does not make many people happy, or comfortable. Nor does the way I confront issues that are dear to me. And I just don't care anymore. I will deal with the world on my own terms, and I feel confident that for the most part I'll do so because that's who I am, not who I think others want me to be.
It's a good feeling.
(It's also worth repeating (over and over and over and over again) that [Char](http://www.livejournal.com/users/xraystar/) is at fault for much of the good in my life too, in case anyone thought that I was ignoring her)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hurray Char. You say that the way you think doesn't make people happy or comfortable, but since I've known you (and it's been awhile), I've noticed that you've changed your way of thinking, or maybe your attitude, and I am more comfortable around you. You've definitely seem like a happier person now and you're a hell of a lot of fun to be with. Just thought I'd let you know.

item.title: Abbot and Costello's Nightmare Movie
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: Along with Mir, Simon, Andrew, and Char (of course) I just watched The Day After Tomorrow, a Jerry Bruckheimer-esque vision of the future of the world, courtesy of Global Warming (insert echoey fright effect here) As one would imagine, it's a fair amount of schmaltz, and the story itself mainly focuses on plucky americans rescuing plucky americans from (plucky) american cities in nasty bad bad situations. Leaving aside the horrible dialog and the wasted effort that they called a plot, I was left (for the last hour of the movie, since there was nothing better to do) thinking about how neat it would be to see more detailed exploration of the results of a climatic cataclysm of this nature. Many fantasy novels I've read over the year are set in a world that only thinly conceals its distant past as our present. The theme of medieval cultures rising from an apocalypse in the present day is one that is fairly common, and truly fascinating to me. Throughout the genres, there have been roleplaying games such as Rifts, Tribe 8 and many more whose names escape me now. There have been novels, from the Dark Tower series to the arguable references to our present in the Wheel of Time. There have been movies... And it's that last, of course, that spurred this line of thought. A line which, I might add, is going absolutely nowhere. I wish I could communicate the mix of emotions that seeing icons of civilization brought to ruin through nature's hand or man's makes me feel. The stories that touch me most, the science fiction whose dark and gloomy side so frustrates me, are the ones that tell the stories _after_ the fall of man. I guess I just watch movies like the Day After Tomorrow and I think that mostly I just want to see what happens after. Not the nice clean save, or the evacuation. I want to see and read about the fall. Morbid?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I don't think it's morbid especially since that is what I too want to see. When there is nothing else to do, I am thinking of what it would be like to be the last one or the only one. post apocalypse, or deserted island, whatever. It's interesting to think what it would be like to be that independant. Maybe *that's" just me.

For myself, I'm more interested in the societal impact of cataclysms like this: What would be lost, what would remain the same. How would a population weaned on the soft life we have adapt to a massive change in quality of life?
What would the world look like 100 years after something like this? I don't want the day after tomorrow, I want something after that.

Speaking of sci-fi with our present thinly disguised as the past, have you ever read Walter Miller's A Canticle for Leibowitz? It's a cyclical nuclear apocalypse novel with a morbid sense of humour and a monastary surrounding a saint who was really just some guy stuck in a fallout shelter (the Sacred Shopping List of Saint Leibowitz is among the venerated relics). Over the course of the novel, the reader is given a society that keeps making the same mistakes over and over again in full knowledge of what came before. I get the distinct impression it's one you'd really enjoy, if you've not read it already.

Could you clarify the final paragraph in your post? "I guess I just watch movies like the Day After Tomorrow and I think that mostly I just want to see what happens after. Not the nice clean save, or the evacuation. I want to see and read about the fall." I've formulated a few thoughts in my head, but have been hesitant to commit comment to paper blog as I'm receiving mixed messages from that last bit. You mention that you wish to see "what happens after" a world-changing disaster in regards to humanity, yet go on to state that you wish to "read about the fall" of human civilization. Are these not two very different things? In regards to the former (after), youve the usual Hollywood suspects; the various Mad Max movies (The Road Warrior being the second and best), the god awful Kevin Costner movies The Postman or Waterworld. The Matrix trilogy fits the bill nicely (and fits too what you ask for in regards to civilization being brought to ruin through natures hand or mans own how about man forcing natures hand and subsequently being enslaved by his own creation?). Regarding the latter (the fall) I cant help but be reminded of the metaphorically-charged remake of Romeros Dawn of the Dead. See humanity. See humanitys decadence. See all Hell break loose. Run, humanity, run! The movie nicely encapsulates the Fall of Man; the boundless (though baseless) optimism, the belief that there must be some way out, somewhere, and the ultimate collapse of human civilization as we know it under its own bloody weight. Hell, looks like I dont need clarification after all; Ive done and answered both. And morbid? Sure. But lets not leave curious out the equation, either.

See, it's both of the above that appeal to me. There's something powerful about the scenes, for example, in AI where they're traveling through the sunken ruins of New York. Stuff like that really gets my 'epic' juices going.

Manager says he doesnt have time to deal with you right now? Hes going to make the time because youve been treated like a criminal shit since this whole ordeal began. Prior to the trip to the dealership, make a point of doing a few things. First of all, letter or no, getting in contact with someone at Toyota headquarters in Canada is vital. Make them fully aware by talking to them personally, not leaving a message whats gone down and how you intend to deal with it. Second, raise a little hell. Contact all the local news networks, their trouble-shooters specifically, and the Better Business Bureau. Increasing the profile of the situation makes it that much harder for Toyota to ignore and all the more likely to resolve the case as it deserves to be. Finally, get a hold of a lawyer. item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: Also worthy of note: Sixty years ago this day, thousands of oft-sung heroes gave their lives on five beaches in Normandy with the intent of breaking the stranglehold the Nazi armies had on Europe. To my enduring shame, my generation and the ones that come after me continue to dismiss and forget the sacrifices made during those times by all those who risked their lives for our freedom. I want to take this platform that I've given myself and say that at least I have not forgotten, nor will I take for granted the freedoms that they won for me, and all those who came after them. item.title: Next, I'll talk about Religion. I promise!
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: First off, I guess I'll get the basics off my chest: _Vote_. I don't care what reasons or excuses you make to yourself to justify your apathy in avoiding the polls, I don't care if you claim that "the system isn't working" or "nobody out there represents my interests." I really don't. And neither should you, in fact. There's a fundamental flaw in your reasoning that would be exposed if you had ever had even the briefest exposure to logic and/or a political education. If you want the system to change, we live in a democracy, dumbass. Your vote _can_ change the system. Alright, now that that's (partially) off my chest, on to the meat of the post. I know that most of the people reading this don't share my political leanings, and that the conversations that have resulted from that difference have been some of the more enjoyable debates I've had. I also know that those debates, much like tectonic plate movement, have an effect on peoples' positions that can usually be measured in picometres per century. But they're fun nonetheless. I very much enjoy the challenge of presenting my position without quite pushing people to Godwin the conversation. I vote Conservative. This is a clear choice for me, based both on my own ethical understanding of the ideal interactions between thinking people and on my personal views of the shape of the modern political landscape. Canada is blessed with a remarkable lack of homogeneity in its political parties, as opposed to the legitimately mockable American two-party system, having as we do "four":http://www.conservative.ca/ "major":http://greenparty.ca/ "political":http://www.liberal.ca/ "parties":http://www.ndp.ca/ , and at least two notable "minor":http://www.blocquebecois.org/ "ones":http://www.marijuanaparty.com/ . Of the four majors, three are represented in parliament already, as is one of the minor ones. My choice is clarified even more by the flaws of the alternatives. Of the five other parties I've described, only one meets with any of my standards for good government, but the other four are interesting in their failures. First, we have the current ruling party, the federal Liberal government. Even leaving aside the issue of corruption, which I'll be the first to admit I just expect in any government that has had unchallenged majority governments for 11 years, the Liberal party is demonstrating more and more that they are only in touch with a small segment of the country, and are more than willing to marginalize and sideline fully half of the country's economic engine based solely on voter scarcity. Adding into the mix the staggering waste of taxpayer money best embodied in the failed gun registry and detailed in the Sea King foolishness, and you have a picture of a party whose ideas can be summed up by the same old Tax and Spend mantra. Next up is the NDP. I'll only cite one example, but there are many, many more to see if you only look. The best view on the NDP is their stated policy of jacking up taxes on the richest 4% of the population by 32.5% in order to raise $80 Billion in revenue. While I'm not an unequivocal believer in trickle-down economics, it does seem to me that squeezing the most productive members of our society (by the only metric that really exists to measure such things that is not completely subjective. I know that there's not a rock-solid argument for income as an indicator, but as I see it, it's the best one we have so far) just because they're successful is a sure recipe for making those people go elsewhere. I know that I would. If there were ever an NDP government, I would look very closely at leaving the country. Which, for some of you, might encourage a vote for them ;). The Green party, the fourth of the major parties on the political scene, is only barely worthy of the name major. They get it, though, because they really are a national party, with candidates in all 308 ridings, and they have a platform that bears close examination. Essentlially, they're pitching themselves as the party of the people, with online voting on their platform issues, and a strong grassroots feel to them. My biggest issue with them is the tendency of environmental issues to piggyback a social and economic policy that I usually find repugnant. However, I don't know enough about the Greens, since they've never had a seat in parliament, to completely discount them. I'll admit that -- if it were suddenly the case that a Conservative vote would be the wrong thing to do, for some reason -- I would probably vote Green in this election as a second choice. The minor parties are much less interesting. The Marijuana Party of Canada is the same old, same old. Good idea, the legalization of harmless drugs, and in fact that's one of the areas in which I disagree with the party I am voting for. Other than that, nothing worth getting excited for. I'm betting on 0 seats for them. Then there's the Bloc Quebecois. This is a party founded on the idea that one province, Quebec, is worthy of special treatment above and beyond all others simply because of their national origin. I'm not going to go into this one on the basis that it's plain dumb. So there's the basics. Nothing special in the latter two, I'll admit, but there _are_ alternatives. Hell, we even have a Communist party running, as well as a Libertarian one. So there's certainly something to serve most people. I hope that someone out there reads this that wasn't going to vote and does. Even if you vote in a way that I'm personally against, please just speak out. We have something rare and special in the history of civilization in the ability to decide who will rule us, and we should use that ability whenever we can. We would be envied by most of the people who have ever lived.

item.title: On medicine
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: From the links of Metafilter comes "this":http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2004-06-13-med-malpractice_x.htm (with attendant discussion). As a consistent supporter of private delivery of healthcare, this sort of thing is the one issue that always presents itself whenever I try to firm up said support to 100%. I have a hard time being unequivocal in my support of such a system when there are examples like this one to caution me. Char and I have frequent talks about the current state of affairs in Canadian healthcare relating to this, and, since she's a medical worker, her input is probably more heavily weighted than most people. What I see in the current public system is excessive costs and rampant waste. A system so weighted down by unionization and skyrocketing costs that it won't be able to survive long enough to support anyone my age into retirement and beyond. As it currently stands, Canada Healthcare has the potential to reach 75% of the budget for each province long before I hit 50. Naturally, I'm a little bit concerned about this, since if there is no public health system and private delivery remains taboo, I'm not sure how it's proposed that I, personally, receive health care as I age. Right now, the question is seen as one that is black and white to parties on both sides of the fence. Private health care advocates, of which I suppose I should count myself one, see the public system as a drain on public coffers whose cost would be better distributed across those that use it most. Public health care advocates tend to see even minor privatization as a first step onto a slippery slope that will lead to a brain drain from the primary public system and to the subsequent ghettoization of public care. I wonder if there's a middle road here. I don't think, given the rising cost of advanced care, that the current model is sustainable. How does one determine who should have access to the new whiz-bang $100,000/year treatment? How can it be paid for? How do you tell a cancer patient, or their child, or their parent, that the treatment that will save them will cost too much? How can you get around this? As my parents' generation, the _largest_ generation, ages, who is going to pay for the immortality that they were promised in their youth? (Mom, Dad, this isn't directed at you specifically. I'm generalizing about your contemporaries. Please don't write me out of the will ;) ) We're talking about a future of health care that is going to have to be discussed and figured out, but proposing alternate methods of handling it is so taboo that no politician will dare do so. I want to see a world where I can get the care I deserve. What 'deserve' means in this context, I don't know. That's what we have to decide. How it's paid for is something that has to be decided too, as well as who provides it. There's a whole other issue in this article, too, about frivolous lawsuits. I don't have enough anger in me right now to really vent on that, so if you really want to know, too bad. You're out of luck.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
What does your mom have to say on the subject? I imagine she knows a lot about it, too. I like public health care. I like knowing I don't have to pay for essential to my life services, but I'm not talking about my recent run in with the hospital, because that's all WCB. I like knowing that I am safe if something happens to me and I will not be left in massive debt should I require emergency surgery or some sort of high priced treatment.
I think that most public health care supporters see private health care as a slippery slope toward what passes for health care in the US, which is more like bureacracy and less like medical practice. I have a good friend who is an insurance agent in the US and so I have first hand horror stories of what it's like to deal with the HMOs who are more interested in a sick person not getting the care he or she needs because it costs too much, and less interested in actually insuring people's health. Frankly, we need to stay away from that kind of thing, and if that means public health care, then so be it. I'd rather pay higher taxes and actually get health services than pay lower taxes but have to cough up at least a few grand if I needed to stay overnight in the hospital, or pay excessive amounts for prescription drugs because of a lack of price caps imposed by the government.
Nonetheless, I agree that something has to change, because of the spiraling cost of health care. Maybe people with colds and the flu can STOP going to the hospital, STAY HOME from work for a few days, take some OVER THE COUNTER medications, REST and recover and NOT put a strain on our hospitals and clinics? HMM? And stop asking for antibiotics when they aren't needed? That'd help, too. I like your idea (which we discussed previously) of charging people to use emerg if they don't need to be there. Oh, look at me, I have a cold, better go to the hospital! I bet that'd stop if you had to pay $20 for wasting their time.

Dammit, I just tried to post something and it apparently got lost. Grr.
Anyway, I wondered what your mom has to say on the subject, being a nurse and probably knowing quite a bit about it.
I like public health care. I feel safer having it, rather than being confronted by an astronomical bill at the end of some essential operation or treatment and having to go into debt to repay, or having to make the tough choice not to be treated (even if it would save my life!) because I can't afford it. I have a friend in the US who's an insurance agent and I've heard all the horror stories about dealing with HMOs who aren't actually interested in insuring people's health, but rather in insuring that said people are denied treatment because it costs too much. I think that's what public health care supporters are worried about. I know that's what I worry about. Maybe there are other private programs that work better, but we don't know about them, because of the glaring light of the US's atrocious health care state. For profit healthcare will never insure proper healthcare, because it costs money and if money is being spent, it isn't making as much of a profit. So I think we need to keep our public healthcare, although I do agree something's got to change or else it will just fall apart. Perhaps all those people who go to the emergency room or to a clinic because they have a cold or the flu could just *stay home* and *rest* and *not* put a continued strain on our medical professionals by taking up their time and demanding antibiotics when a few days in bed with some neocitran (or whatever other *over the counter* drug) would do it. I like your idea (which we previously discussed) of charging idiots at the emergency room money for coming in when they don't need to. I'd think twice about going to the hospital if I knew I'd have to pay $20 if I didn't need to be there. But only if I didn't need to be there- real emergency cases should not have to pay.

Interesting ideas from both of you. About all I have to say now is to agree that my generation is going to be a huge burden on yours, I'd like to think that when I started first using the health system, 51 years ago, I have contributed enough to cover what I will use. It's too bad that I know that there is no possible way the bureaucracy (sp?) actually thought that far ahead. By the way, I'm too lazy to change my will.

Good to know that ;) With regards to the burden being placed on the system as the population ages, I don't think that the healthcare bureaucracy is necessarily _unaware_ of the issues with regards to it. Instead, since most of them are of the age group in question, I think that there's little motivation to change a system that won't fail until after they've died and thus don't care about. As with many things, the motivation is a selfish one, and I'll admit to a fair jag of cynicism on the subject, but I do believe that people are inherently selfish with regards to that.
The US system is not a shining example of anything, that's the problem. The US system varies so dramatically from place to place that it can only exist as an example of the varied ways that healthcare is delivered. HMOs are one of the biggest problems in that system, in my opinion, since the reason that individual, uninsured healthcare is so expensive and getting expensive insurance is the only option is that HMOs have negotiated steep discounts for medical services (as much as 50%, I hear) beyond what Joe off the street would pay. So they make more money while the uninsured person pays full price. It pains me to admit it, but maybe it's necessary to place some controls on pricing in order to clamp down on this.
Oh. And one more thing: The weblogging system will sometimes flag a comment for moderation based on words in it, as checked against a list of common spam words. Don't fret too much if it doesn't post the comment right away. I'm working on a way to have the moderation request sent to the commenter instead of to me so that you can auto-approve your own comments (not something most comment spammers are going to do)
It's also worth noting that this very comment was not approved either :).
okay, so sorry about the double post. I didn't realize what was happening. You can take one of them off, if you wish, since they pretty much same exactly the same thing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That's scary! and coming from me, who believes that politicians should reveal their sources of financing, and corporations reveal their books, that is something.

The Billiard Club on Whyte is safe. At least it was when I was there in May.
That's very scary. I don't want people having access to my driver's licence. It's _mine_. Politicians should reveal the sources of financing, and corporations open their books, I agree. But having access to that kind of personal information? What is this: the Canadian version of the Patriot Act, only in bars? Yeesh.

KNOW AND ASSERT YOUR RIGHTS!
The new Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (I believe it came into effect January 1st 2004) states that no business can deny a product or service if a customer refuses to give up private information which is non-vital to the product or service. Barwatch scanning is clearly non-vital, and so any person entering a club with barwatch can assert their right to not be scanned, and the club is not allowed to deny you entry on these grounds.
Reference:
http://www.privcom.gc.ca/information/02_05_d_08_e.asp
"The law requires organizations to:
obtain your consent when they collect, use or disclose your personal information; supply you with a product or a service even if you refuse consent for the collection, use or disclosure of your personal information unless that information is essential to the transaction; collect information by fair and lawful means; and have personal information policies that are clear, understandable and readily available.

Further to this, I'd like it if anyone who notices additional bars doing this would be so kind as to drop me a line so that I can update this from time to time.
I'm looking into ways of ensuring that this posting stays visible so that it can be a bit of a resource, although I'm not sure how important my little end of the web is to that :)

item.title: We get the government we deserve, don't we?
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: As should be known by now, Canadians have spoken, and what they've said is, essentially, "Please, sir, can I have some more?" Faugh. With everything that has come to light about the workings of the Liberal party in this country, we as a nation chose to re-elect a party led by a man who hides his own companies in offshore tax shelters. We chose to re-elect a party that has demonstrated itself incapable of being honest towards its electorate. We chose -- for the _fourth time running_ -- a party that has broken more campaign promises than some parties even _make_ (GST, anyone?) We truly do get the government we deserve. Here's to more of the same.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Or perhaps the government we want.... a lot of people had to go and vote Liberal, which means they either don't care about scandals or broken promises, or trust the Liberals more than they trust anyone else. Which is saying a lot, when you think about it. If so many Canadians trust the Liberals above all the other parties, despite scandals and what not, it's not a good sign for those other parties.
Too bad the Greens didn't win. They seem to have some idea of what's going on and what reasonable action to take. Too bad they only got one lousy seat, if it was even them that got the 1 indy seat.

Or, possibly, people are so afraid of change that it's trivially easy to turn them against a party that has yet to take office in order to prove itself one way or the other. I hear a lot of talk about how the Conservatives will do this or that, but despite the individual leanings of _some_ of their candidates, I still see their policy of free votes on contentious issues clearly and repeatedly stated.
It's a big step from "We'll allow free votes in parliament on (issue) so that (issue) will be decided democratically instead of by the courts" to "We will unilaterally rule that (issue) will be decided according to our Christian teachings."
But it's one that you, Mel, have made, and it's one that many on the centre-to-left spectrum of politics feel free to toss about as an accusation.
Oh, and the Greens (regrettably) didn't even get one lousy seat -- the independent candidate in BC is an ex-Alliance MP who didn't win the nomination for the Conservative party in his riding (I remember hearing that there was some fuss about that).
However, hopefully in the next election the Green party will be allowed into the debates and be accepted as a real part of politics in this country. I, for one, could comfortably vote for them if they show themselves to be relatively centrist in their social policies. It'd be nice to see an environmentally-minded libertarian-spirited party in politics, and that would be one that I could seriously look at as a choice for government.

Liberal... a hard buy. But having Harper would have been better? If he had been in power earlier we would have been sending out 'peacekeepers' off to Iraq in that little shit skirmish between Uncle George and old whatshisname.... I'm just glad that so many people voted this year. A friend of mine told me that Alberta set a new record for the amount of people that turned in a ballot this year. A pretentious rebel might have gone in and turned in a blank ballot and then begin whining and crying about how everything is gone to shit. Other than using up your constitutional right to vote what does this accomplish? But... that's my opinion and I do see the 'justice' behind it. Might I add one last thing... sometimes people complain about the government we live in as if we are forced to live in some sort of facist regime. I know it's not perfect but Canada is undisputably one of the best countries in the world.

I think that there's a critical difference between turning in a spoiled ballot and not voting at all, although admittedly it's splitting hairs. The former, at least, demonstrates that the citizen in question isn't a lazy shit.
With regards to a Conservative government and involvement in Iraq, well...
How about this: One thing that I keep hearing is "If (party) had been in charge during (incident), (undesirable outcome) would have happened." May I please be the first to introduce you to a useful "site":http://www.datanation.com/fallacies/explan/untest.htm for logical fallacies.
These statements are untestable. It can not be proven, nor is it logical to argue from it as a premise. You can only hypothesize. What's more, and in the vein of the same fallacy, you have no evidence that Paul Martin's Liberal government wouldn't have done the same. It's meaningless. Leaving aside for a moment the rightness or wrongness of the occupation of Iraq, I would suggest that it's a poor point to use in choosing who to elect.
Canada is definitely my preferred place to live. I refuse to (as some have suggested) just "go live in the US, if you like them so much!" because I really do believe that Canada's flaws are fixable and that, given those being fixed, this would be a great place to live in every respect.
When is the EMLS party's organization meeting?

If I had any illusions about garnering votes and realistic political chances, I'd form one.
But I'm too pragmatic to expend the wasted effort.

I didn't say they would unilaterally rule according to their Christian teachings. I know there are members of the Conservative party (former Alliance members, too) who support gay marriage, but what we don't need is a party who, in general, will support things like pro-life or no marriage for gay people (not to mention the ones who advocate that it should be illegal). the right wing parties seem to be the only ones who attract politicians who will vocally bring their religious opinions into their job. I'm not saying it doesn't happen in the centrist and leftist parties, but in those parties, religious beliefs tend not to be brought out or used in determining how one will vote. And we don't need anyone dragging church and state together- we've seen how well it works in the US. God is one whose side again?
And there are other reasons not to like the Conservatives, it's not just that people run and hide at the name. Stephen Harper's economic plan was not very stable, and a lot of Canadians (I think) feel that the a Conservative party will not uphold our social systems the way they are, at least for the most part. I'm not saying there isn't room for improvement. Of course there is.
Also, I believe (please correct me if I'm wrong) that part of Harper's platform included more military cooperation with the US, which is not to say "let's go bomb the hell out of Iraq", but at the moment, the US needs some limits placed on its military intervention, not more encouragement. I guess there would be a lot of Canadians (if I'm right about this point) who don't want an increased military presence in concert with that of the United States.
As for the "evil we know" sort of mentality, well, yes, that works. Because Canada is not technically a two party system, it sure acts like it, and it's only on the provincial level that parties that aren't Conservative or Liberal will win. On the federal level, it seems that most of the country thinks there are only two choices. And so the Liberals won this time. So they've been in office for 10 years. So they broke promises. The Alberta Conservatives have been in office for over 30 years and have also broken promises. They still get voted in as well. Of course they've done some good for our province; we have a balanced, (or nearly balanced?) budget and are close to paying off the debt. Same with the federal Liberals. They aren't all bad.
And no one will ever lower your taxes. Remember: income tax was only to support the Second World War.
First World War, actually. /retreats back to his cave

Gah. It's that complacency with the corrupt status quo combined with evidence-free assumptions of flaws in the alternative that frustrated me so much throughout this campaign. All the Liberal party did was claim that Harper was "un-canadian" in his values. Over and over and over again.
It's funny. In the US, fear is a tool of the right wing -- fear of terrorists, fear of crime, fear of child porn, etc... In Canada, it's the other way around; fear is a weapon used by the left to paint the right with a broad tinge of red, white and blue. As opposed to actually debating the issues.
You make a funny comment, Mel, about the pro-life, anti-gay-marriage contingent that you admit exists in both parties. First off, if so many people are on those sides, perhaps (this being a _democracy_, after all) it might be worth considering that the majority should perhaps rule? I'm not advocating it myself, because I sit firmly against the religious values on those two issues, but it's awfully arrogant to claim that "We don't care what the people want, this is the *right* way!" Further, I believe that a free vote on the subject would serve the excellent purpose of putting both issues to bed for good, since most likely they would result in a pro-choice, pro-gay-marriage law. But free votes won't ever come into it under the minority government of the Liberals -- too much risk of a non-confidence result.
Religious beliefs are "used in determining how one will vote" regardless of whether it's announced. It's a nice dream to think otherwise, but it's false. Everyone votes their conscience when given the chance to do so.

I thought it might be WW1, but I couldn't remember. thanks for the correction.
I really don't think that a referendum on the gay marriage or abortion issue would result in putting either issue to bed for good, as there would still be people out there who would fight to get either one overturned, no matter which way it went.
And voting along your conscience and voting according to your religious beliefs aren't necessarily one and the same.

one thing to note and add is the implication of the word "we" in the statement "we get the government we deserve". let's not forget that this election saw, nationally, only a (and i'm going off what i heard on cbc radio in jasper for the exact number here, so don't flog me if i get this wrong) 60.7% voter turnout. this is the lowest turnout since eighteen hundred something, and a gross disappointment considering how tight this race was.
so when you say "we", keep in mind that (give or take) two out of every five potential voters didn't care enough about their own voices to cast a ballot. who knows what the shape of things would be had they taken the time...
They, too, get the governent they deserve; one that doesn't care what they think.
touche.

item.title: A last shot at convincing
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: I know I harp on this one a lot, but perhaps "this":http://isc.incidents.org/diary.php?date=2004-06-29 will scare the last few holdouts amongst you away from using Internet Explorer for anything secure, or better yet, anything at all. As discussed on slashdot, the gist of this is that a sneaky program (that can install itself invisibly when you view a webpage that tries to install it) can insert itself into your browser and read your secure information (that'd be _credit cards_, folks!) *before* it's encrypted. There _are_ alternatives, though: "FireFox":http://www.mozilla.org/products/firefox/ is one, and it's the one that I use. "Opera":http://www.opera.com/ is another, although it's not really my favourite. Also, there's the old standby, "Netscape":http://www.netscape.com/ although I wouldn't recommend it personally, and Netscape's spiritual successor "Mozilla":http://www.mozilla.org/ which is basically the big brother of Firefox. Seriously, folks. This is serious business. Don't take chances unnecessarily.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Is this only for EI on Windows, or on Macs, too? I don't use it, but I just want to know.

Since you use a Mac, odds are small that any of this is an issue to you. However, Firefox and Mozilla are available on the Mac. Use Safari, though, or ... there's another one that's good on the Mac whose name escapes me at the present. They're good browsers.

item.title: Approaching Health in a New Way
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: Metafilter has linked an article about the rising costs of healthcare in the USA, one that -- like several things I've read recently -- raises some uncomfortable questions about privately-insured healthcare. Feel free to read it and ... well, it's interesting. A notable quote in it: "I'm beginning to think that running a risk-pool that actually protects its members and running a risk-pool for profit are diametrically opposed endeavors." Against my better judgement, I might be forced to come to agree with this idea. I'm trying to figure out a way to reconcile the profit motive with the goal of managing risk for things like healthcare that bear such a high cost and are so heavily used, and I can't really find a way to do so. Is it maybe that socialized medicare works better? I don't know, but it needs thinking about. I do know that the healthcare system we have in Canada is not sustainable, but I don't know what should replace it. I think that eventually what is going to have to happen is some hard questions about what is covered are going to be asked, or else the system will collapse under its own weight. One idea, from someone with whom I routinely disagree, is here. But I find myself hoping that we don't go into US-style healthcare anymore, which is ... new.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: How about a somewhat combined thingy. Are all the newest, trendiest procedures actually medically required orcan some of them be let out, all or in part, to a profit parrallel system. Look at pro-sports, they already have their own system of treatments that bypass the official medical system, they want it they pay for it and as far as I can tell, by not causing any delay to the masses.

Well, the US system frankly sucks, and should never be held up as an ideal except for maybe "here's how _not_ to do it!" But maybe what you're looking for is having to pay for services but everything had a cost cap established by the government. Kind of like paying premiums, but on an individual, as required basis, for whatever things that the government deems privately payable. However, then there's the problem of sliding scales (let's face it, not many of us can cough up $3000 per round for chemo or $40k for heart surgery) and the problem of which things not to cover by taxes and premiums. Certainly for profit can't work, because it's right there in the name: _for profit_. A for profit insurance company has no interest in covering people to the best of their abilities, because that's not profitable. And we don't need to follow the US example unless we want to have a third rate medical system and people arguing in the emergency room over admission fees rather than actually getting treated.
I have read those articles, though. I'm too lazy. Above is just my ideas.

item.title: Weather; You like it or not.
item.dc:creator: offby1

item.title: G'morning. I'm bored, already!
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded:
Oddly enough, I've found that having eight days off over the last two weeks is too much.
Oh, I'll admit, if I had _known_ that they would be free in advance, it would be a whole different story -- I could have planned some, made some progress on projects, etc. But, since it's a completely day-to-day issue, I find myself more or less at loose ends for the duration.
So, right now, I'm hoping that the skies stay clear for a good long stretch, so that I can return to work tomorrow, no doubt to get filthy and hot lugging a pump and 4-inch hose around clearing out low spots on the jobsite. Still, it's getting paid, and that's a good thing. And it's activity, also a good thing.
Anyway, though, today at least will be spent trying to make a fractal draw on my screen. SWT is proving to be a bit of a different beast when it comes to outputting images, so I have a little bit of a hassle to work through. Not least because I don't really 'get' graphics programming, which leaves me with a bit of a struggle to get things together. I can grok string work, but for some reason the way that nearly every java app and framework handles images just leaves me cold. It's essentially impossible to just create a simple image and show it.
Faugh.

item.title: Biblical, yo.
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: What a downpour. It started about 14:45 just before Char had to leave for work, and as we got ready to drive there, it was picking up to mammoth volumes including hail and low, threatening clouds. We drove her to work, gingerly, and then I made my way home. Returning home, I was forced to detour repeatedly, avoiding flooded stretches of road in places like Calgary Trail North Even avoiding those, I was stuck four times in a position where I had to go through 30 metres or so of 30cm-deep water to get where I was going. Picked up a couple of ladies who had had their van stall out just south of one avenue and drove them the remaining 15 blocks to their house. I felt pretty good, very good-samaritan. Then, I got home. In my basement was 2cm of water covering 80% of the TV room floor, having come in via the saturated ground through permanent cracks in the foundation. So, a more or less frantic removal of furniture was accomplished with the timely aid of "Aaron":http://www.spaz.ca who made the voyage, nay, _odyssey_ to assist me through streets made into rivers by this massive flood. Life is icky, cold, and wet. I know, because to see if the roads were clear, I tossed on some shoes I never wear and hopped on my bike to tot around the neighborhood. Most of the water is gone, so I am going out in a minute to pick up some ribs. I deserve them. Hopefully Jacques gets here soon with the shop-vac so that I can suck up some of the water here. ### Update Here are some pics from the disaster (be warned, the large images are _quite_ large): That's all of them for now.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I sure hope my peas are ok. That Lemongrass is sure hating it too... but amazingly enough, it is still alive and growing considering it hates to move so much.

The peas, hon, are hating it big time. They're all snapped off, generally cracked and messy. Now that Jacques is here, we've shop-vacced the hell out of the room. So far, I'd say we've pulled nearly 100 L of water out of the carpet, and it's still pretty wet at the west end of the room. Insanity. So, tomorrow we'll be working at this, too.
I was wondering how you went through the storms, fun eh? Last time I saw my peas, they were fine.

item.title: Restricted News
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: In my search for news articles about yesterday's incident, I ran into a peculiarity of the news agencies in this city. The "Edmonton Journal":http://www.edmontonjournal.com/ has moved from a free site that shows only the top stories in its paper to a subscription model where all but the headline story must be accessed by paid subscribers. The "Edmonton Sun":http://www.edmontonsun.com/ on the other hand has remained free for access via the web. The Journal, to me, is a better newspaper. It's got more balanced coverage, and while it does pander, it panders to politics, not to the lowest common denominator. However, when it comes to tracking down city news, I'm ill-inclined to pay for a paper subscription when the competing paper is offering much the same local news for free, and international news is only a "click":http://news.google.com/ away. I wonder how well that's working for them? (side note: I notice that even rampant commercialistm must bow to nature. Life's funny like that)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: All the newspapers owned by CanWest have done this, I believe (ie: The Vancouver Sun). I hate it, too. I like the Vancouver Sun but now I can no longer read it. The Globe and Mail, on the other hand, is still free to all.

item.title: Not sure why this comes to mind
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: In a posting on slashdot about "tired.com":http://www.tired.com (via Slate) and the confessional aspects thereof, I stumbled across "this gem":http://slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=114414&cid=9694920 of a comment, with regards to the work/life balance. It's funny that -- despite the advances in labour-saving technologies -- the amount of time and effort we put into maintaining ourselves in a lifestyle of any kind has increased steadily. There was a time, and it's not too terribly long ago, that -- for example -- six children could be raised with only one full time income (although I'd be willing to bet that Grandma was doing some kind of work on the side. Care to elaborate, Dad?). Now, in order to _own a house_, it's not required that both parties work, but it's pretty close. And if you want to have kids, unless you happen to be in the lucky upper 10% of the income demographics, good luck affording it. What happened to the future wherein we would all be free to pursue intellectual improvements? The future of leisure, as our advancements (as a species, through our technology) liberated us from menial labour? As usual for this kind of thing, I have a few fuzzy, undirected opinions on it. The thing about a life free from labour is that the part of me that believes strongly in capitalism as a superior method of distributing limited resources rebels at the idea of an indolent life. If one doesn't work for what one wants, by what right does one claim it? This feel natural to me, and the evidence of the world (the repeated failures of the far end of the socialist spectrum) would seem to bear me out, at least in part. The problem with this instinct is, of course, that it's predicated on limited resources. In a world of plenty, even I would be willing to admit that capitalism is unnecessarily harsh. Of course, there are still issues there -- imagine if there was enough (food|water|energy|$good) for everyone to have what they _need_. Then imagine what bizarre ideas people might have about their own needs, especially if the cost to them was zero. That's just one hiccup. The cynic in me suspects that the failure of our labour-reduction dreams stems more from wanting more than it does from anything else. Some exceptions may apply, most notably in housework; does anything -- anything _at all_ -- in your housework arsenal _really_ reduce the amount of time you spend cleaning? Still, in the rest of life, we want more and more. We've been raised to go for the best we can get, even if we don't necessarily deserve it. Witness, for example, the ridiculous salaries paid to cleaning staff in hospitals. The aforementioned cynic has another idea, too, one that's even less popular. There are people who are by nature or inclination flat-out incapable of intellectual pursuits. For one reason or another, be it blatant stupidity, simple ignorance, or plain old apathy, they are unable or unwilling to turn their minds to anything more challenging than remembering what time and channel Canadian Idol is on. These people are ill-suited to anything beyond tossing garbage or toting heavy chunks of pipe around. So what would we do with them, in this hypothetical society of plenty? Would they simply sit and soak up the largesse that surrounds them, supported by the strength of other intellects? The confusing thing here is that the people working longer hours than they used to are not this shallow end of the gene pool, they're the ones that have a glimmer of potential. I see it most in my industry, of course, but it's the ones with degrees who have ambition and long term plans who are slaving away. Meanwhile, the ones with MBAs and connections are (as a reply to the comment above says) "moving on to the salad course during the air-conditioned bonus announcement party. They're working less," and something about that feels wrong to me. I'm not really sure where I'm going with any of this. I know that there's something wrong, but I can't put my finger on it, nor can I really suggest a solution, even one too harsh to ever be implemented.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: As far as mom, no, she did not really do any other work by the classical definition now in use. Leterally, she managed the household, garden, cleaning, feeding et al. Any little things she earned money for, wedding cake decorating etc., she did this more for her own satisfaction than to actually earn income. As far as the rest of your posting, I'm going to have to reread and think about it, interesting.

People are greedy. They want more than their neighbors. Then their neighbors want more than them, then they need more than their neighbors. Who needs a car? MAYBE 5% of us? Probably less. Who NEEDS a television? NONE of us!
As for the rest of it, Will it ever be perfect? When one side is deciding what is enough for everyone, there are bound to be problems.

item.title: Words that I hate 1: FUD
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: FUD(Fear, Uncertainty, Doubt) has to be one of the most irritatingly over- and inappropriately-used words in the ever-raging debate over Free Software. Originally an acronym for Fear, Uncertainty, and Doubt, FUD was used originally (depending, of course, on whom you ask) to describe Microsoft's agitating about the widespread adoption of open source solutions. This is not the usage that inspires loathing in me. In the present day, FUD is used as a catch-all term for anything that disagrees with the poster's strongly-held views on Free Software. Usually used by rigid proponents of the [FSF](http://www.gnu.org/) view -- that all software should be free of restrictions, except the restriction that you're not allowed to add restrictions. Yep, wacky. Just imagine the debates on this one -- there are whole scads of licenses for software that just get stupid-picky. So, we have an acronym that definitely served a valid purpose once upon a time. Now, though, it's over-used and under-comprehended. It's a mistake of the 'net, one that we would be well served to let slip into the dustbin of history, except for the fact that there are thousands of pale, bloated, pimply-faced open source zealots out there ready to spout "That's FUD" at the top of their whiny-ass virtual voices at the slightest sign that someone is impugning the software license that they choose to worship. The word is FUD, and I hate reading it.

item.title: Immaterialism
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded:
It's a peculiar thing for me, given my generally materialistic bent, to be in a position where I simply don't want anything material -- not actively, at any rate.
Over the course of the last year, I've been given two gifts that, between them, have transformed my life from one of material desire to one where I now have a hard time thinking of what I could ask that anyone ever give me as a gift.
One was the [iPod](http://www.apple.com/ipod/) that dad bought me for christmas, and this is a big one. Since getting it, I have listened to more music (in 8 months) than the five years previous all together. It's brought me back to a mental place where I can appreciate music at my leisure, and a place where I both seek new bands and appreciate old ones that I had let fall by the wayside. For example, right now I'm listening to Rammstein. Hard to go wrong with silly-ass techno-influenced german heavy metal :)
The other, though, is a bit smaller and would seem to be a really simple, small thing: This [coffee maker](http://www.cuisinart.com/cgi-bin/index.cgi/en/item.cgi?item_id=DGB-600BC) has become indispensable in the week and a half since it came into our house. Imagine the joy of having fresh-ground, fresh-brewed coffee waiting for you every morning. It's so nice, I don't know what else to say, other than it's just that nice.
Yes, I'm gushing over a coffee maker. Deal with it.
This stuff makes me happy, and leaves me only coveting books and skydiving. And computer parts, but those are a whole other category unto themselves. C'est etrange, non?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It IS an awefully nice coffee maker.
Take this second for yourself, up, down, let go.
oddly enough, I'm at a point in my life where there is a long list of material things I want. I can never think of a Christmas wish list; now I'm working on it in August! yeesh

item.title: Just Chilling
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded:
It's a pretty nice evening here. I'm sitting on the couch in the living room, Char just beside me reading her Dark Tower book and Ivan on my lap.
I don't have to get up in the morning, and I have plans to get some quality geeking in when I do.
The weather is windy and cloudy, threatening rain.
I saw the Bourne Supremacy tonight, and other than a strong desire to throttle the cinematographer, it was excellent, tense and fast and exciting.
The book that I'm reading... Okay, _one_ of the books that I'm reading is about Faerie and it's really nifty. Anyone that likes fantasy should really read Tad Williams' _The War of the Flowers_ at their soonest convenience.
Amongst the other books that I'm reading is Neal Stephenson's _The Diamond Age_, which looks to be an interesting take on the cyberpunk idiom, and Bruce Schneier's _Applied Cryptography_ -- required reading for any cryptonuts in the crowd.
Right now, I am relaxed. And life is good.

item.title: Seeing is Believing
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: Spurred by a random comment from a co-worker of mine last night during a post-work wings & beer gathering, I decided today to look into the information on the back of my new Alberta Driver's Licence. For those of you who haven't seen one yet (I saw many of them when working as a bouncer, and I just recently got my own) they have a strip on the back that consists of some form of binary encoded information. My question was, of course, _what_ information. So, I've been phone-tagging this morning, to a few government departments, where at least one of them told me that it's just what's on the front of the license, excluding the picture. I'm reasonably sure that this is the case, but it does seem to me that there is too much information on the back for it to be that simple. As near as I can tell, there are 5,824 bits of information stored on the back, or 728 bytes. Even leaving aside compression, and making a conservative estimate as to the size of the data fields, there is about 300 bytes of textual data on the card. Say, a maximum of 400. Now compression can reduce text to sometimes as little as 25% of its size, although one can't guarantee that compression is being used, since it's highly likely that the information is encrypted, which usually resists compression. That being said, what is the rest of the info? Some of it would be checksum data to validate the info on the strip, but I can't imagine that all of it would be. What information about myself am I carrying around? The departments I spoke to are reluctant to provide me with real information about it, although I should be receiving a call today to make an appointment with Registries to go in and at least see what they see when my license is scanned. It's a small step, but I'd like to verify at least that much. I know that it's not likely, but if any of my readers has more information about this, or even knows how to go about hunting more down, I'd love to hear it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm fairly certain it has your status as a driver on it as well, as when I was pulled over, I had a drivers licence I had lost, and gotten replaced. Its a long story, but they were able to ascertain that I had no tickets and a missing/stolen licence within 2-3 mins. Which, I'm thinking, is less time than it would take to call it in and wait for someone else to run it

That's probably more because the police cruisers have wireless computers that connect to a central database and can look up your information.
A bit of an update to this: Having called Registries and asked that they return my call tuesday, so that I would actually be home, I got a call yesterday (wednesday) while at work asking me to call them. Since I don't get home until 6PM or later, that doesn't help me too much, does it?
Faugh. Go government bureaucracies!
Is it possible that the strip only comes in one size, and no more info is stored on it?
As it happens, that's probably the case. However, the one size is still larger than is necessary for the data it could store, thus leaving it open to storing more than would appear to be there.
Maybe it just says when you've been naughty. Naughty boy. :)

When you find out, let me know. Specifically, let me know what it says about you. I am very interested...
And kudos for noticing something like that- I didn't even really look at the back of my new licence

item.title: Required Reading
item.dc:creator: offby1
item.content:encoded: I've known for a long time that, while I'm not a total hermit, I both need less human contact than other people, and tire of it sooner. The fact of the matter is, I find forcing myself to conform to others' expectations of me is exhausting, both physically and mentally, and it leads to some of the more antisocial behaviour that I've engaged in in the past. I'm thinking, though, that [this book](http://www.amazon.ca/exec/obidos/ASIN/1569245134/qid=1091244370/ref=sr_8_xs_ap_i1_xgl/702-2225080-2583201) ought to be required reading for anyone that wants to understand me a bit better, and also for anyone that has a friend that they find to be a bit distant at times, for reasons they don't really understand. _Party of One_ has put to words many of the things I see in myself. Although it's not a word-for-word expression of who I am and how I feel about things, it is more accurate than not. I am a loner, to a large extent. And although the people in my life enrich it and make it a better place, there are frequent times that I can't handle any of them, and I just need to be away from it all. It's a good book, and I hope that someone gets something valuable from reading it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Does it have big print and lots of pictures?

Ah... it's so good to be back on line! I didn't realize how much I'd miss it, how much it would drive me crazy not to be able to just check my email and my blog roll...
As for being a hermit... I used to be like that, too, then I went to work at the Pickton Farm and suddenly became a lot more social and wanting to hang out with people. could have used that hermit-ness right now, though, as the people here all suck and don't care to include me in anything and all my friends are back in Alberta or Vancouver. Yeah!

If you remember that CD I was looking for for so long, one of the songs on it that is right up my list of songs is the title song, words of ernest. Listen to it, you will probably really understand the song and know exactly how close you and me are in this arena.
